column1: When was volleyball invented?
column2: Volleyball was invented on February 9, 1895, by William G. Morgan at a YMCA in Holyoke, Massachusetts. Initially called "mintonette," it was designed as a less physically demanding alternative to basketball.

column1: When did volleyball become an Olympic sport?
column2: Volleyball became an Olympic sport in 1964 during the Tokyo Summer Games. Beach volleyball was later introduced as an Olympic sport in 1996.

column1: Who is the best male volleyball player?
column2: The best male volleyball player in the world as of 2025 is Alessandro Michieletto from Italy, recognized for his outstanding performances throughout the year. Other top players include Lucas Saatkamp and Matt Anderson, who have also made significant impacts in the sport

column1: How many people are on each team on the court?
column2: There are 6 people on each team

column1: What was the original name of volleyball?
column2: Volleyball was originally called mintonette, a name derived from the game badminton

column1: When were the first volleyball Championships held?
column2: The first men's World Championship was held in 1949. The first women's championship followed a few years later, in 1952

column1: How is the serving team chosen?
column2: The serving team is chosen by a coin toss before the match begins. The winner of the toss can choose to serve or receive the first serve.

column1: What are points called in volleyball?
column2: Points

column1: If you score a point during a spike, what is it called?
column2: Scoring a point with a powerful, untouched spike is called a "kill." It signifies an attack that immediately ends the rally and scores a point.

column1: What is the number of times a team can hit the ball without passing it over the net?
column2: A team is allowed a maximum of three consecutive contacts with the ball. The third contact is typically used to send the ball over the net to the opponent's side.

column1: What is the player who specializes in defense called?
column2: The player who specializes in defense is called the "libero." This player wears a contrasting jersey and has specific limitations, such as not being able to attack the ball above the net height.

column1: When the ball hits the floor on one side of the net, it counts as a point for the other team. What type of scoring is this called?
column2: This scoring system is called "rally scoring." It means a point is awarded on every rally, regardless of which team served, making the game's length more predictable.

column1: How many sets are in a volleyball game?
column2: A standard volleyball match consists of 5 sets. The first team to win 3 sets is declared the winner of the match.

column1: In which way do the teams rotate?
column2: Teams rotate their positions in a clockwise direction. This rotation happens immediately after they win the serve back from the opposing team.

column1: What is it called when a server steps past the serving line?
column2: When a server steps on or over the end line before making contact with the ball, it is called a "foot fault." This results in a serving error and the serve goes to the other team.

column1: Which player position serves?
column2: The player in the right-back position is the one who serves. Players rotate into this position to become the new server for their team.

column1: How many substitutions in a game are allowed on each team?
column2: Each team is allowed a maximum of 12 substitutions per set. A player can be substituted in and out, but starting players can re-enter a set only once, and only to their original position.

column1: What is a dig?
column2: A dig is a defensive move made to prevent the ball from touching the court after an opponent's attack or spike. It is typically performed with the forearms or hands.

column1: What are the names of the two referees?
column2: The two referees are commonly called the "first referee" and the "second referee." They are also informally known as the "up referee," who stands on the stand, and the "down referee," who works on the court floor.

column1: How many positions are there on each side of the court?
column2: There are 6 distinct rotational positions on the court for each team. These correspond to the 3 front-row players and 3 back-row players.

column1: How many timeouts is a team allowed per game?
column2: Each team is allowed two timeouts per set. These timeouts are typically short, strategic breaks to discuss tactics with the coach.

column1: For how many seconds does a timeout last?
column2: A regular timeout in volleyball lasts for 60 seconds. During this time, players can go to their bench for coaching and hydration.

column1: How does the referee know if the ball is in or out of line?
column2: The referee relies on line judges positioned at the corners of the court. These officials watch the court lines and signal with flags whether the ball landed "in" or "out."

column1: What happens when the ball lands on the line?
column2: If any part of the ball lands on the line, it is considered "in" play. The entire ball must land completely outside the line to be ruled "out.

column1: What is it called when a back-row player jumps from in front of the 10-foot (3-meter) line and attacks the ball above the net?
column2: This is an illegal play commonly called a "back-row attack fault." Back-row players must take off from behind the 10-foot line to legally hit the ball if it is entirely above the height of the net.

column1: Is a player allowed to touch the net during a live rally?
column2: Generally, no. If a player touches any part of the net between the antennas while the ball is in play, it is a "net fault," and the other team wins the rally. Incidental contact from the ball driven into the net usually does not stop play.

column1: What is the difference in scoring for the deciding final set (e.g., the 5th set) in a match?
column2: Unlike the first four sets which are played to 25 points, the deciding set (if necessary) is typically played to only 15 points. The team must still win by a margin of 2 points.

column1: What is the "10-foot line" (or 3-meter line) on a volleyball court used for?
column2: The 10-foot line, also called the attack line, separates the front row from the back row. It primarily regulates where back-row players can legally attack the ball above net height.

column1: What happens if the ball hits an antenna during play?
column2: The antennas are vertical rods attached to the net directly above the sideline. If the ball touches an antenna during play, it is considered "out" and results in a fault for the team that last touched it.

column1: What is a "lift" or "carry" in volleyball?
column2: A lift or carry is a fault called when the ball comes to rest on a player's hands or body during contact, rather than being clearly rebounded or hit. The contact must be clean and momentary.

column1: What is a "pancake" in volleyball defense?
column2: A pancake is a desperate defensive move where a player flattens their hand against the floor just as the ball is about to land, allowing the ball to bounce off the back of their hand and stay in play.

column1: In indoor volleyball, can the libero serve in a single match?
column2: This depends on the specific rules being used. In many collegiate and high school rules, the libero is allowed to serve in one specific rotational position. In some international professional rules (FIVB), they may be allowed to serve multiple times.

column1: What is a "joust" in volleyball?
column2: A joust occurs when two opposing players simultaneously contact the ball above the net, pushing against each other. Play continues, and neither team is considered to have faulted unless the ball is caught or thrown.

column1: What is a "mis-hit" or "tool"?
column2: While "tool" can sometimes mean using the block, a "mis-hit" is often called a "block abuse" or "wipe." This is an offensive strategy where the attacker intentionally hits the ball off the opponent's block so it deflects out of bounds.

column1: What is volleyball?
column2: Volleyball is a fast-paced team sport where two teams of six players, separated by a high net, aim to score points by grounding a ball on the opposing team's court.
